all_text_timv: Sutnar, Ladislav Collection of Ladislav Sutnar graphic design ephemera,  1942-1969 1.209 linear ft. Collection is open for research This collection of 19 print items includes iconic works by Czech-American graphic designer, artist, and theorist Ladislav Sutnar (1897-1976), as well as documents related to the 1961 exhibition Visual Design in Action. Purchased with funds from the  Dorothy Foehr Huck Libraries Acquisition Endowment; 2015 Born 1897 in Plzeň, Bohemia, Ladislav Sutnar was educated in Prague, where he also began his long career as a designer. Sutnar quickly gained recognition for his early work in publication, exhibition, industrial, and stage design, while teaching at Prague's State School for Graphic Arts through the 1920s and '30s. In 1939, Sutnar traveled to the U.S. to design the Czech pavilion for the New York World's Fair. At the same, the Nazi annexation of Czechoslovakia dissolved the government there, and Sutnar chose not to return. He settled in New York City and continued to work prolifically in a number of different design disciplines. He is best known today as a pioneer of "information design, " establishing the use icons, typography, and grid layouts to streamline the display of large amounts of information. He died in 1976 in New York, New York. English
